Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Hydrogels for Intervertebral Disc Repair
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a reliable treatment method for patients with intervertebral disc herniations undergoing spine surgery. There are approximately half a million individuals who undergo a discectomy procedure each year, where each procedure costs an estimated $15,000-$50,000. Studies on healthcare economics found that for every 100 patients undergoing the procedure, approximately $300,000 is spent on revision surgeries due to the failure of the initial surgery (reherniation). Therefore, of the total population undergoing discectomy each year, there is the potential to save $1.4 billion annually through prevention of revision surgeries if reherniation can be prevented. Additionally, using this hydrogel technology to localize other reparative implants inside the intervertebral disc would enable more therapies to potentially obtain regulatory approval and improve the quality of spine repair. Commercialization of the hydrogel technology will allow the development and clinical use of a variety of biologic and mechanical implants for spine repair.

This I-Corps project further develops injectable biomaterials for sealing defects and securing implant devices in minimally invasive procedures with emphasis on spinal applications. Intervertebral discs are cartilaginous tissues in the spine that connect adjacent vertebra, absorb shock and allow flexibility during motion. In intervertebral disc degeneration, lesions in the stiff outer tissue allow the gelatinous inner tissue to herniate and compress surrounding nerves. Discectomy, the current standard intervention for intervertebral disc degeneration, relieves pain but does not actively heal the diseased tissue. Clinical research has found significant reherniation rates following discectomy procedures with various efforts attempted to use repair implants that prevent reherniation and restore lost disc tissue. These implant materials and devices are not tightly secured within the disc, and thus current strategies are often flawed by reherniation around the implant or migration of the implant itself. This project is developing injectable hydrogels to secure disc repair implants, effectively preventing migration of the implants and herniation of disc material. In pre-clinical studies, hydrogels used with other devices prevented herniation and largely restored native intervertebral disc mechanical properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
he NSF I-Corps program was an invaluable experience that instilled all involved with a deeper entrepreneurial mindset and better understanding of how to successfully start a company. The award was spent on attending national I-Corps events in Denver, CO, and travel for customer discovery interviews across the United States to understand the potential opportunity for a new therapeutic to improve spine surgery. Stephen (entrepreneurial lead), JJ (technical lead), and Dave (industry mentor) kicked off and closed the national program in Denver, where they learned about all aspects of entrepreneurship related to high-tech companies. While it was uncomfortable at first to receive incessant constructive criticism and alter their business model canvas on the fly, the team eventually learned to embrace the NSF instructor’s feedback to better their entrepreneurial vision. The team traveled to San Diego, CA, Honolulu, HI, New York, NY, and Rochester, NY to better understand their potential customer’s needs, talking to influential spine surgeons, hospital executives, and medical officers at insurance agencies.

            The initial business idea was a therapeutic gel that could be applied during spinal surgery to help heal part of the spine, since nearly 25% of patients going through this particular procedure require revision surgery. The team initially thought that patients and spine surgeons would be the primary customer segments, and developed a business model revolving around these two key players. The team quickly learned within the first week that while spine surgeons are definitely one of the most important customers, but the patients undergoing surgery do not a critical role in the use of various spine therapies. After a dozen customer discovery interviews, the team’s focus shifted to spine surgeons, executive hospital administrators, and chief medical officers at insurance agencies. Our initial value propositions to each of these customer segments were somewhat vague early in the process, but we eventually tied the value propositions to monetary gain as a driving force for each of these customer segments. The I-Corps process helped our team understand how complicated the healthcare space is, and acknowledge that there are many parties involved outside of these three customer segments that will also need significant attention if we were to launch a company in this space.

            The entire team learned a ton about entrepreneurship, commercialization, and customer relationships throughout I-Corps, but ultimately decided not to pursue the spine therapeutic any further. The I-Corps experience gave the team a great understanding of the spine healthcare space, and enough conviction to decide the opportunity was not as profitable as initially thought. As such, no further business developments have been made related to licensing agreements, company formation, SBIR submissions or further funding. While this idea did not necessarily lead to a successfully startup company, each member of the team is highly interested in entrepreneurship and would like to continue pursuing high-tech ideas to improve society. The NSF I-Corps program also gave each team member valuable professional skills that can be used in a variety of settings outside of entrepreneurship.


Last Modified: 03/04/2020
Modified by: Lawrence J Bonassar
